And none of that takes less than a second to execute now.

Since the assassin update where lethality was introduced and assassination windows increased (and arguably before then) the already powerful ADC role became even more problematic because consistent heals and shields made it impossible for assassins to kill the enemy ADC - as their window of vulnerability is way too short for an assassins combo to be performed.

Most assassins take 1-2 seconds to pull off their combo, which often isn't enough to even kill an adc unless they're extremely fed. Zed's combo for example will usually leave an ADC at around 20% hp after flash, heal, and then shields from supports which are almost always active. That would be fine, because lots of cds were blown in order to save the ADCs life, but the adc can simply drain tank back to full hp in a couple auto attacks because minions and monsters have little to no armor (thus huge crits grant even larger lifesteal)  - so the entire trade almost always ends up in the favor of the ADC.

Why do you think assassins are almost never picked in competitive play? Peeling and shielding supports are so god damn strong combined with that ADCs are capable of deleting entire teams while also having insane safety and good early game that whichever bot lane wins almost always results in a victory for them.

Almost without exception top teams in the LCK and CSL (Korea + China) put their strongest players in the ADC and support role. The only notable exception is probably Faker, but his adc is almost as good as he is. If bot lane wins, you win the game almost by default.

This used to be true.  But then the assassin update happened, and most major assassins have a ~2s window baked into their burst.

Ever tried playing leblanc against an ADC past midgame these days?  The ADC will just right click and kill you before your passive or chains even finish proccing.

Assassins still have a lot of mobility and special niches that allow them to still go against that - For example Kha ult and Akali w. Fizz e is a good one and there are several others. There are also exceptions still to this (such as Talon) that still have good mobility/niches paired up with the one shot.

Assassins are champions expressly designed to apply lots of burst, though. By contrast, marksmen are supposed to be weak to assassins, as they're meant to be squishy and focused on persistent damage, rather than burst. It's okay for a marksman or mage to get bursted down by an assassin, provided they had the chance to outplay them, because that's intended to be how fights go. By contrast, an assassin should lose to a mage or marksman only if they get outplayed, and getting killed by autoattacks while getting in range is, for most assassins, not something they can outplay while doing their job properly.
